long-description.p: Originally just a small fishing village, Howth is now a busy suburb of Dublin. The village of Howth spans most of the northern part of Howth Head, a Peninsula which is connected to the rest of Fingal via a narrow strip of land at nearby Sutton. In the past, Howth could become isolated from the mainland during stormy weather and high tides.

The island of Ireland's Eye, part of the Howth Estate, lies about a kilometre north of Howth harbour, with Lambay Island some 5 km further to the north. A Martello tower exists on each of these islands with another tower overlooking Howth harbour. These are part of a series of towers built around the coast of Ireland during the 19th century. At the south-east corner of Howth Head is the automated Baily Lighthouse. Howth is a popular area for birdwatching and sailing, and is also popular with anglers. It is also an extremely popular area for tourists in the summer.

p.b: To find the cache do the following
1-Go the above co-ordinates and note the amount of steps on the harbour wall. Call this A.
2-Go to N53.23.A99 W006.03.988. Take note of this important date and change into numerical format. Call this number B C D E F G H.
3-Go to 53.23.(BCD+46) W006.0H.(FGH-767) take note of the date of the unveiling. Again change this into numerical format and call this I J K L M N O.

You are now ready to find the cache!
The final co-ordinates are: N53.23.KBE W006.0(O-L).(M-G)(N-(J+K))(I+L)

long-description.p: Please bring a pen or pencil to sign the log.

p.font: This is a very popular area and stealth is required to grab the cache undetected as it is very exposed. Please rehide the cache quickly and carefully. Thanks!

p.b: This cache has been adopted from

ul.li:
2010-06-16T19:00:00Z : Found it by RoobyDoo
What a cracking multi! Had a splendid lunch in the Boody Stream before setting off. Managed to see the seals, almost every inch of the harbour and have a very nice ice cream aswell. Retrieving the cache required extreme stealth, but it was well worth it. Thanks for such a great time in Howth RD

2010-05-25T19:00:00Z : Found it by schnuckel1
At a certain point of time we wished we could fly or had a boat with us... [;)] But as we are neither birds nor fishes we had to walk through this pretty harbour. Logged at 11:34
TFTC schnuckel1 from Germany [# 777]

2010-05-21T19:00:00Z : Found it by Crannyn
2nd one today.Really pleased as it's our first multi cache that we were able to work out ourselves without help from friends. Perfect weather as it was lovely to be able to sit down ,in the sun and work out the coords. It was a real coincidence, we were only here yesterday. junior crannyn and friend were standing on top of it ! TFTC
[This entry was edited by Crannyn on Saturday, May 22, 2010 at 7:30:46 AM.]

2010-04-18T19:00:00Z : Found it by Spark_ie
Got the first stage a number of weeks ago - the last time I was in Howth, however I didn't have the time to grab the rest of the stages. Today however, with the help of the bike, I got thes rest of the numbers no problem, and found the cache easily. TFTC, Spark_ie

2010-04-10T19:00:00Z : Found it by lenik1
Found it easily after a lovely stroll around the harbour [:)]

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Howth Harbour
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Originally just a small fishing village, Howth is now a busy suburb of Dublin. The village of Howth spans most of the northern part of Howth Head, a Peninsula which is connected to the rest of Fingal via a narrow strip of land at nearby Sutton. In the past, Howth could become isolated from the mainland during stormy weather and high tides.


The island of Ireland's Eye, part of the Howth Estate, lies about a kilometre north of Howth harbour, with Lambay Island some 5 km further to the north. A Martello tower exists on each of these islands with another tower overlooking Howth harbour. These are part of a series of towers built around the coast of Ireland during the 19th century. At the south-east corner of Howth Head is the automated Baily Lighthouse. Howth is a popular area for birdwatching and sailing, and is also popular with anglers. It is also an extremely popular area for tourists in the summer.


To find the cache do the following


1-Go the above co-ordinates and note the amount of steps on the harbour wall. Call this A.


2-Go to N53.23.A99 W006.03.988. Take note of this important date and change into numerical format. Call this number B C D E F G H.


3-Go to 53.23.(BCD+46) W006.0H.(FGH-767) take note of the date of the unveiling. Again change this into numerical format and call this I J K L M N O.


You are now ready to find the cache!
The final co-ordinates are: N53.23.KBE W006.0(O-L).(M-G)(N-(J+K))(I+L)




Please bring a pen or pencil to sign the log.



This is a very popular area and stealth is required to grab the cache undetected as it is very exposed. Please rehide the cache quickly and carefully. Thanks!
